ud5.5:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
ud5.5:1.3: Now, at that time it was the sabbath, and the Buddha was sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
ud5.5:2.1: And then, as the night was getting late, in the first watch of the night, Venerable Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ud5.5:2.2: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha has been sitting long.
ud5.5:2.5: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the mendicants.”
ud5.5:2.6: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.
ud5.5:3.1: For a second time, as the night was getting late, in the middle watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ud5.5:3.2: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha has been sitting long.
ud5.5:3.5: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the mendicants.”
ud5.5:3.6: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.
ud5.5:4.1: For a third time, as the night was getting late, in the last watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ud5.5:4.2: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha has been sitting long.
ud5.5:4.7: Please, sir, may the Buddha recite the monastic code to the mendicants.”
ud5.5:5.4: Then he focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the Saṅgha.
ud5.5:5.5: He saw that unethical person, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved, sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha.
ud5.5:5.6: When he saw him he got up from his seat, went up to him and said,
